description:
Every alert attached to the response header provides information about occuring errors, potential problems and system events, that should be properly handled by the requester for smoother user experience ðŸ˜‰

### Alert level 

Every alert is issued with a certain severity level, explained below:

|*Level*|*Description*|
|---|---|
|**fatal**|A serious failure affecting application stability.|
|**error**|An error or unexpected condition, which lead to an action failure, but doesn't affect the whole application.|
|**warn**|Indication of a potential problem.|
|**info**|Informational message that highlight the progress of an action at coarse-grained level.|
|**debug**|Designates fine-grained informational events and detailed information on the flow through the application and involved third-party systems, which is most useful to debug an application.|
|**trace**|Designates finer-grained information than the *debug* level, including internal system events. *Available only for on-premises configurations*.|

The alerts of severity below *'warn'* are not reported by default. These levels are available only for development and issue resolution purposes and require corresponding traceability enabled for the requester.

### Alert code 

The numeric code of alert designates a certain type of alert and specific conditions it is issued for.

### Alert details 

The attributes supplying details of the alert provide various helpful information for its proper handling. 

|*Attribute*|*Description*|
|---|---|
|timestamp|The date and time when the corresponding event occured.|
|element|Points to a certain *element* of interation, which is related to the alert.|
|message|A localized wording explaining the occured event.|
|link|A URL of some reference documentation about the situation highlighted by the alert.|
|traceId|A special reference Id that may be used for finding this alert in system trace log.|

Some useful best practices for proper handling of errors and warnings can be found here â€” <http://www.userjourneys.com/blog/ux-guidelines-for-error-handling/>.
